Post.title: ACM-ICPC 2018  H Ryuji doesn't want to study( )
Post.content:
Ryuji doesnt want to study

$sum{a[i]}$$sum{(n-i)*a[i]}$($triangle[i]$)


$[2,5] = 2\cdot4+3\cdot3+4\cdot2+5\cdot1$$$query(2,5) = (triangle[5]-triangle[1]) -(7-5)\cdot(sum[5]-sum[1])$$



$query(2,5)$
$$\begin{align}
query(2,5) & = (2 + 3 + 4 + 5 )+ (2 + 3 + 4)+(2+3)+(2) \\\\
& = (sum[5]-sum[1]) + (sum[4]-sum[1])+(sum[3]-sum[1])+(sum[2]-sum[1]) \\\\
& = \sum_{i=2}^5 sum(i)-(5-3+1)\cdot sum(1)
\end{align}$$
$$
query(l,r) = \sum_{i=l}^rsum(i)-(r-l+1)\cdot sum(l-1)
$$

()

()

\end{align}$$

# [](https://www.lydsy.com/JudgeOnline/problem.php?id=2299)
# 
a,b$(a,b), (a,-b), (-a,b), (-a,-b), (b,a), (b,-a), (-b,a), (-b,-a)$$(x,y)$

$(x,y)$
<!--more-->
# Input
$t,(t<=50000)$

t$a,b,x,y  (-2*10^9<=a,b,x,y<=2*10^9)$
# Output
$t$YN
# Sample Input
3

2 1 3 3

1 1 0 1

1 0 -2 3
# Sample Output
Y

N

Y

#



(2,1)+(1,2)=(3,3)




(-1,0)+(-1,0)+(0,1)+(0,1)+(0,1)=(-2,3)
# 


1. $x+=2a,y+0$
2. $y+=2b,y+0$
3. $x+a,y+b$
4. $x+b,y+a$
$3$$4$$1$$2$$3$$4$

$k_1\cdot (a,b)+k_2(b,a)=(x,y)$
1. $k_1\cdot a+ k_2\cdot b = x$
2. $k_1\cdot b+ k_2\cdot a = y$
$1$$2$$k_1$$k_2$

$x$$y$$gcd(a,b)$
```c++

using namespace std;

long long gcd(long long a,long long b)
{
    return b==0?a:gcd(b,a%b);
}

bool love(long long x,long long y,long long g)
{
    return x%g==0&&y%g==0;
}

int main()
{
    long long t,a,b,x,y;
    for(scanf("%lld",&t); t; t--) {
        scanf("%lld%lld%lld%lld", &a, &b, &x, &y);
        long long g = gcd(2 * a, 2 * b);
        if (love(x, y, g) || love(x + a, y + b, g) || love(x + b, y + a, g) || love(x + a + b, y + a + b, g))
            puts("Y");
        else
            puts("N");
    }
    return 0;
}
```

# [](https://baike.baidu.com/item/%E6%AC%A7%E6%8B%89%E5%AE%9A%E7%90%86/891345?fr=aladdin)
$$a^{\varphi(n)}\equiv 1(mod\:n),\:gcd(a,n)=1$$

$n$$n$$n$$\varphi(n)$
$\varphi(6)=2$$6$$6$$1,5$
<!-- more -->
# ()
$$  a^b \equiv
\begin{cases}
a^{b \%\varphi(p)},  & \text{gcd(a,p)$\:$=$\:$1}\\\\  
a^b, & \text{gcd(a,p)$\:$$\not=$$\:$1,$\: b\:$< $\varphi$(p)}\\\\
a^{b \%\varphi(p)+\varphi(p)},&\text{gcd(a,p)$\:$$\not=$$\:$1,$\: b\:$$\geq$ $\varphi$(p)}\end{cases}
\pmod p$$  


$1.\:$$n$$p$$\varphi(p)=p-1$$p$$1$$p$$p$$p$$ \varphi(p)=p-1$

$1$
$a^{p-1}\equiv 1(mod\:p),gcd(a,p)=1$$p$$\varphi(p)=p-1$
$a^p\equiv a(mod\:p)$$a$$p$

$2.\:$$n$$p$$\varphi(p^a)=(p-1)\cdot p^{a-1}$$p^a$$p^a-1$$p$$p^{a-1}-1$$1\to p^a-1$$p$$\varphi(p^a)=p^a-1-(p^{a-1}-1)=(p-1)\cdot p^{a-1}$

$3.\:$$n$$a$$b$$a$$b$$\varphi(a\cdot b)=\varphi(a)\cdot \varphi(b)$$x=\phi(i)$$a\cdot b$
$$(S):\begin{cases}
x_1\equiv t_1(mod\:a) \:(gcd(t_1,a)=1)\\
x_2\equiv t_2(mod\:b) \:(gcd(t_2,b)=1)
\end{cases}$$[](https://baike.baidu.com/item/%E5%AD%99%E5%AD%90%E5%AE%9A%E7%90%86/2841597?fromtitle=%E4%B8%AD%E5%9B%BD%E5%89%A9%E4%BD%99%E5%AE%9A%E7%90%86&fromid=11200132&fr=aladdin)$t_1,t_2$$(S)$$[1,a\cdot b)$$t_1$$\varphi(a)$$t_2$$\varphi(b)$
$\varphi(a\cdot b)=\varphi(a)\cdot \varphi(b)$

$4.\:$$n=p_1^{e_1}\cdot p_2^{e_2}\cdot p_3^{e_3}......p_k^{e_k}$$p_i$
$\varphi(n)=n\cdot(1-\frac{1}{p_1})\cdot(1-\frac{1}{p_2})\cdot(1-\frac{1}{p_3})......(1-\frac{1}{p_k})$
$2$$3$$p_i$$p_i$$p_i^{e_i}$$2$$\varphi(p_i^{e_i})=p_i^{e_i}-1-(p_i^{e_i-1}-1)=p_i^{e_i}\cdot (1-\frac{1}{p_i})$$3$$\varphi(p_1^{e_1}\cdot p_2^{e_2}\cdot p_3^{e_3}......p_k^{e_k})=\varphi(p_1^{e_1})\cdot \varphi(p_2^{e_2})\cdot \varphi(p_3^{e_3})......\varphi(p_k^{e_k})$$\varphi(n)=n\cdot(1-\frac{1}{p_1})\cdot(1-\frac{1}{p_2})\cdot(1-\frac{1}{p_3})......(1-\frac{1}{p_k})$

# 

$1.\:\:\varphi(p)=p-1$
$2.\:\:\varphi(p\cdot i)=p\cdot \varphi(i)\:\:(p\%i=0)$
$3.\:\:\varphi(p\cdot i)=(p-1)\cdot \varphi(i)\:\:(p\%i\not=0)$
(^_^)

```C++
void initPhi(int n)
{
	phi[1] = 1; //(1) = 1
	for(int i = 2; i <= n; ++i){
		if(!vis[i]){
			phi[i] = i - 1; //1
			prime[++cnt] = i;
		}
		for(int j = 1; j <= cnt; ++j){
			if(i * prime[j] > n) break;
			vis[i * prime[j]] = 1;
			if(i % prime[j] == 0){ //2
				phi[i * prime[j]] = phi[i] * prime[j];
				break;
			}
			phi[i * prime[j]] = phi[i] * phi[prime[j]]; //3
		}
	}
}

```

Post.title: A(fwt-)
Post.content:
Niuniu has recently learned how to use Gaussian elimination to solve systems of linear equations.
Given n and $a[i]$, where $n$ is a power of $2$, lets consider an $n\times n$ matrix $A$.

The index of $A[i][j]$ and $a[i]$ are numbered from $0$.
The element $A[i][j]$ satisfies $A[i][j] = a[i\, xor\, j]$,
XOR

Let $p = 1000000007$.
Consider the equation
$A x = b \pmod p$
where $A$ is an $n \times n$ matrix, and $x$ and $b$ are both $n \times 1$ row vector.

Given $n, a[i], b[i]$, you need to solve the $x$.
For example, when $n = 4$, the equations look like
$A[0][0]\cdot x[0] + A[0][1]\cdot x[1] + A[0][2]\cdot x[2] + A[0][3]\cdot x[3] = b[0] \pmod p\\\
A[1][0]\cdot x[0] + A[1][1]\cdot x[1] + A[1][2]\cdot x[2] + A[1][3]\cdot x[3] = b[1] \pmod p\\\\
A[2][0]\cdot x[0] + A[2][1]\cdot x[1] + A[2][2]\cdot x[2] + A[2][3]\cdot x[3] = b[2] \pmod p\\\\
A[3][0]\cdot x[0] + A[3][1]\cdot x[1] + A[3][2]\cdot x[2] + A[3][3]\cdot x[3] = b[3] \pmod p$
and the matrix $A$ can be decided by the array $a$.

It is guaranteed that there is a unique solution $x$ for these equations.

Input

The first line contains an integer, which is $n$.
The second line contains $n$ integers, which are the array $a$.
The third line contains $n$ integers, which are the array $b$.

$1 <= n <= 262144$
$p = 1000000007$
$0 <= a[i] < p$
$0 <= b[i] < p$

Output

The output should contains $n$ lines.
The $i$-th(index from $0$) line should contain $x[i]$.
$x[i]$ is an integer, and should satisfy $0 <= x[i] < p$.

$$A\times x = b \pmod p$$
$A$
$$ \left[
\begin{array}{ccc}
a_0&a_1&a_2&a_3\\\\
a_1&a_0&a_3&a_2\\\\
a_2&a_3&a_0&a_1\\\\
a_3&a_2&a_1&a_0
\end{array}
\right] $$

$a$$fwt$()
$a$$b$$fwt(a)\cdot fwt(x) = fwt(b)$$x$

$fwt(a)$$fwt(b)$$x[i] = \frac{b[i]}{a[i]}$$fwt(x)$

Niuniu has recently learned how to use Gaussian elimination to solve systems of linear equations.
Given n and $a[i]$, where $n$ is a power of $2$, lets consider an $n\times n$ matrix $A$.

The index of $A[i][j]$ and $a[i]$ are numbered from $0$.
The element $A[i][j]$ satisfies $A[i][j] = a[i\, xor\, j]$,
XOR
Post.more:
Let $p = 1000000007$.
Consider the equation
$A x = b \pmod p$
where $A$ is an $n \times n$ matrix, and $x$ and $b$ are both $n \times 1$ row vector.

Given $n, a[i], b[i]$, you need to solve the $x$.
For example, when $n = 4$, the equations look like
$A[0][0]\cdot x[0] + A[0][1]\cdot x[1] + A[0][2]\cdot x[2] + A[0][3]\cdot x[3] = b[0] \pmod p\\\
A[1][0]\cdot x[0] + A[1][1]\cdot x[1] + A[1][2]\cdot x[2] + A[1][3]\cdot x[3] = b[1] \pmod p\\\\
A[2][0]\cdot x[0] + A[2][1]\cdot x[1] + A[2][2]\cdot x[2] + A[2][3]\cdot x[3] = b[2] \pmod p\\\\
A[3][0]\cdot x[0] + A[3][1]\cdot x[1] + A[3][2]\cdot x[2] + A[3][3]\cdot x[3] = b[3] \pmod p$
and the matrix $A$ can be decided by the array $a$.

It is guaranteed that there is a unique solution $x$ for these equations.

Input

The first line contains an integer, which is $n$.
The second line contains $n$ integers, which are the array $a$.
The third line contains $n$ integers, which are the array $b$.

$1 <= n <= 262144$
$p = 1000000007$
$0 <= a[i] < p$
$0 <= b[i] < p$

Output

The output should contains $n$ lines.
The $i$-th(index from $0$) line should contain $x[i]$.
$x[i]$ is an integer, and should satisfy $0 <= x[i] < p$.

$$A\times x = b \pmod p$$
$A$
$$ \left[
\begin{array}{ccc}
a_0&a_1&a_2&a_3\\\\
a_1&a_0&a_3&a_2\\\\
a_2&a_3&a_0&a_1\\\\
a_3&a_2&a_1&a_0
\end{array}
\right] $$

$a$$fwt$()
$a$$b$$fwt(a)\cdot fwt(x) = fwt(b)$$x$

$fwt(a)$$fwt(b)$$x[i] = \frac{b[i]}{a[i]}$$fwt(x)$
